name: INTRO TO MECH DESIGN

values.comments:
This hands-on, project-based course covers the fundamentals of the modern mechanical design process, from needfinding and brainstorming to the basics of computerized manufacturing and rapid prototyping. Topics include: product definition (needfinding, observation, sketching, and brainstorming); computer-aided design (part creation, assemblies, and animation using SolidWorks); fundamental engineering design practices (material selection, dimensioning, tolerances, etc.); basic computer simulation and analysis; and rapid prototyping (laser cutter, 3-D fused-deposition modeling, and an introduction to computercontrolled machining).

Students generally agreed that the course was “a lot of independent experimentation to finish the assignments.” Most students felt that it was a great course in which they learned a lot and were able to “use the material [they] learned in other courses quite successfully.” However, some complained that it “took up too much time,” was “very work intensive,” and required “too much time commitment.” Most students said that even though it was difficult and they had to work very hard for it, the course was “fun” and “worthwhile.”

Students felt that Professor Fiene “in general taught an excellent course.”  Many described him as “intelligent” and “understanding,” and they appreciated that he “took time to explain the coursework.” However, some students felt that he “lacked the theoretical knowledge to teach this course,” given that he often couldn’t explain the “theoretical background” of some assignments and had to “bring in external professors” to explain them. Some students found him to be disappointing because “he [was] rarely available to help students” and “he cancelled every other lecture.  Since the class met once a week, some students felt that they rarely saw him.

MEAM 101 students generally felt that this course was “the basis of all mechanical engineering,” and “a great course to learn solidworks.” Some students felt that it should be required for MEAM majors. Some agreed, “It would be perfect for Fall of freshman year.”  Others felt that the course “covers fundamental mechanical skills and design strategies that [can be] incredibly useful for future courses such as MEAM 247 and 347.” It was highly recommended to all engineers, whether they are MEAM majors or not.
